chapters.title: Chapter 1
chapters.content:
When I was little, my uncle Pete had a necktie with a porcupine painted on it. I thought that necktie was just about the neatest thing in the world. I would beg him to wear it whenever he came to visit. I would stroke it and stare at it. For my ninth birthday, he sent me the necktie in the mail. With it came a note: "Happy birthday. Now it's yours."

That was the best present I ever got.

I kept the necktie on my dresser for a while. I looked at it every day. Then I put it in a drawer. I kept it there until I was about fifteen. Then I forgot about it.

Did my uncle Pete ever know how much I loved that tie? Does he know that I still have it, stuck in a box somewhere in my closet? I thought about him when I first saw her.

When she first appeared, I thought of that porcupine necktie. I thought of my uncle. I thought of the question I never asked him: "Where did you get it?"

She was elusive. She was today. She was tomorrow. She was the faintest scent of a cactus flower, the flitting shadow of an elf owl. We did not know what to make of her. In our minds we tried to pin her to a corkboard like a butterfly, but the pin merely went through and away she flew.

She was new. She was us. She was different.

She was Stargirl.

I was in the TV studio when she first showed up. It was a Monday, the first day of school, tenth grade. I was student director of Hot Seat, a program on our local in-school cable station called MAHS (Mica Area High School) TV.

I looked up. I said to Kevin: "What is that?"

Kevin Quinlan was my best friend and co-producer of Hot Seat. He turned. He looked.

"A girl," he said.

"But who?" I said.

At that moment, people walking by in the hallway stopped, turned, looked.

I looked at Kevin. Kevin looked at me. His face said: I don't know.

"Someone new," he said.

And she was gone.

chapters.title: Chapter 2
chapters.content:
By lunchtime the word was out: "A new girl in tenth grade." Her name was Stargirl Caraway.

Stargirl.

We wondered about that. What kind of name is Stargirl? We laughed. We didn't know what to make of her. The next morning we looked for her. We didn't see her.

"Maybe she quit," said Kevin.

But she was there. We just couldn't see her. She was surrounded by a mob of curious students. They watched her walk down the hallway.

She was homeschooled. That's what they said. She had never set foot in a school before now. Her parents had taught her themselves, at home. In the old days that might have gotten them tossed into jail. Now it was legal.

So she didn't know anything about us. She didn't know that when a new student shows up, he or she is expected to move warily onto the campus, checking things out, sounding people out.

She didn't know that she was supposed to lay low, not to make waves, to find out who the natives were and what their customs were and then to act accordingly.

She carried a ukulele, for crying out loud. She sang "Happy Birthday" to people. She danced in the rain. She talked to strangers. She sang to her pet rat.

When she walked through the halls, the other kids parted before her like the Red Sea. They didn't want to touch her. They didn't want to catch whatever she had.

But you couldn't help looking. She was impossible to ignore. Her long skirt swished about her ankles. Her lunch consisted of a hard-boiled egg, a few sticks of celery, and a handful of sunflower seeds.

She wore no makeup. She wore her light brown hair to her waist. But mostly what you noticed was her. Just her.

She laughed when there was no joke. She danced when there was no music. She had no friends yet she was the friendliest person in school.

In her first week at school, she turned the place upside down.

What pet did Stargirl have?

chapters.title: Chapter 3
chapters.content:
"She's real," said Kevin.

Kevin Quinlan was my best friend. We were in his bedroom, our favorite hangout. We had tried many times to explain what made the place so comfortable. Maybe it was the uncluttered floor. Or the fact that nothing hung on the walls.

We were sprawled on his bed, eating peanuts, listening to classic rock on his stereo, and talking about Stargirl.

"I think it's a trick," I said. "I think she's putting on an act."

Kevin snorted. "Why would she do that?"

"I don't know." I tossed a peanut at him. "Why does anybody do anything?"

Kevin caught it and flipped it into his mouth. "Maybe she's just being herself. Did you ever think of that?"

I had thought of that. And I didn't know what to make of it. Being yourself was one thing. Being Stargirl was another.

Nobody was that different. At least not publicly. Nobody played ukulele in the cafeteria. Nobody sang "Happy Birthday" to total strangers. Nobody wore pioneer dresses and antique jewelry.

As far as we knew, nobody had a pet rat. And nobody, I repeat, nobody, called herself Stargirl.

"So what's her game?" I said.

"Her game?" Kevin sat up. He stared at me. "What if it's not a game? What if she's real? What if she really is that different?"

"That different," I repeated. "Nobody is that different."

"Prove it," he said.

I couldn't. Not then. Not now.

quiz.question: Where did Leo and Kevin have their conversation about Stargirl?
What did Kevin think about Stargirl's behavior?
options: He thought it was an act
He thought she might just be being herself
He thought she was from another country

chapters.title: Chapter 4
chapters.content:
Mica Area High School—MAHS—was not exactly a hotbed of nonconformity. There were individual variants here and there, of course, but by and large the student body dressed alike, talked alike, ate alike, even moved alike.

We all had access to the same TV and magazines. We dressed in the same kinds of clothes, listened to the same kinds of music. We wanted to be different. We wanted to be noticed, to stand out. But our idea of different was to change the length of our haircuts by an inch, to wear one brand of sneakers instead of another.

We may have thought we were different, but we weren't that different. Not Stargirl different.

At the beginning of the first week, she got a lot of stares. And there were laughs—snickering behind hands—especially at the ukulele. As the week went on, the snickering turned to calls: "Hey, Stargirl, where's your broom?" "Where's your wand, Stargirl?" "Make me disappear!"

But she didn't seem to notice. She didn't seem to hear. She just kept walking the hallways, alone, her long skirt swishing, her ukulele by her side.

And then came Friday.

The first pep rally of the year. Football season. MAHS versus Red Rock. It was a big deal. The cheerleaders got the bleachers pumping, the players jogged in to wild applause, the band played the school anthem.

And then, right in the middle of all the hoopla, Stargirl stood up. She was in the front row of the bleachers. And she began to dance.

Not with anyone. Just herself. Just dancing.

The music stopped. The cheerleaders stopped. Everyone stopped. And stared.

She danced alone in the sudden silence.

quiz.question: What was MAHS known for according to the narrator?
options: Not being a hotbed of nonconformity

quiz.question: What happened at the first pep rally?
options: Stargirl stood up and danced alone

chapters.title: Chapter 5
chapters.content:
Kevin and I looked at each other. We were standing near the doors at the far end of the gym. In front of us a thousand students sat frozen in the bleachers.

Down on the gym floor, Stargirl was dancing. As suddenly as it had stopped, the music started again. But nobody moved. Nobody made a sound.

We might have been looking at a movie, some faraway scene playing out on the gymnasium screen. The music went on, the cheerleaders eventually returned to their routine, but the crowd just stared at the little dance going on in the front row.

I can't remember how long it lasted. Maybe only a few seconds. Maybe a minute. But it seemed much longer.

And then someone laughed. One person. The spell was broken. People turned back to the pep rally. The usual yelling and stomping resumed.

After the rally, Kevin and I walked out together.

"Okay," I said. "What just happened?"

Kevin shook his head slowly. He seemed dazed. "I don't know."

"I mean, who does that? Who dances alone at a pep rally?"

"Nobody," said Kevin. "Nobody does that."

"She's either the bravest person in the whole school," I said, "or the craziest."

"Or both," said Kevin.

"Or both," I agreed.

We walked on in silence. Something had changed. I could feel it. The whole school could feel it. Something had changed, and it had to do with that girl. That strange, impossible girl.

Stargirl.

quiz.question: How did the crowd initially react to Stargirl's dancing?
What did Leo conclude about Stargirl after the pep rally?
options: She was trying to be popular
She was either the bravest or the craziest person

chapters.title: Chapter 6
chapters.content:
"We gotta get her on Hot Seat," said Kevin.

It was two weeks into the school year. Kevin and I were eating lunch in the TV studio, as we often did. Hot Seat was the most popular show on MAHS-TV. Each week we put a post in the Hot Seat—a tweedy, secondhand easy chair we had picked up at Goodwill. The tweedy chair sat in the middle of a powerful spotlight. The tweedy person sat in the hot glare of tough questions.

We grilled them about their lives, their opinions, their most embarrassing moments. It was good-natured stuff, mostly. But sometimes the questions got edgy. We had gotten complaints from parents, even threats to cancel the show.

"Think she'll do it?" I said.

"Why wouldn't she?" said Kevin. "Everybody wants to be on Hot Seat."

That was true. To be invited on the show was an honor. It meant you were somebody. But Stargirl? The rules didn't seem to apply to her.

"I don't know," I said. "She's different."

Kevin grinned. "Exactly. That's why she'd be perfect."

I thought about it. The weird clothes. The ukulele. The pet rat. The dancing. There was so much to ask her. So much we wanted to know.

"Okay," I said. "Let's do it."

We decided to wait. We wanted to observe her a little longer. We wanted to have our questions ready. We wanted the show to be special.

In the meantime, the school continued to buzz about her.

quiz.question: What did Kevin want to do with Stargirl?
Where did Kevin and Leo get the Hot Seat chair?

chapters.title: Chapter 7
chapters.content:
She did things.

She was always doing things. Unexpected things. Impressive things. Weird things.

She left a small bouquet of wildflowers on the desk of a student whose grandmother had died. How did she know? Nobody knew.

She left a congratulations card on the desk of a kid who had just gotten his driver's license. How did she know? Nobody knew.

She cheered for the other team. Not just our team. Both teams. At basketball games, at football games. She cheered when the opponents scored. She cheered when they made a good play.

The cheerleaders didn't know what to do with her. At first they tried to ignore her. Then they tried to shut her up. Then they gave up.

She sang "Happy Birthday" in the lunchroom to anyone whose birthday it was. She found out, somehow. She knew.

She carried a canvas bag with her everywhere. In the bag was her ukulele, some books, her lunch, and Cinnamon, her pet rat. Cinnamon rode on her shoulder sometimes, through the hallways, into classrooms.

Teachers didn't know what to do. Rats weren't allowed in school. But this wasn't just any rat. This was Cinnamon. This was Stargirl's rat.

She talked to everyone. Not just the popular kids. Everyone. The nerds, the jocks, the druggies, the nobodies. She didn't seem to notice the difference.

She noticed other things. Things the rest of us missed. A kid sitting alone. A kid crying in the hallway. A kid who needed a friend.

She noticed. And she did something about it.

quiz.question: What did Stargirl leave on a student's desk whose grandmother had died?
What was unusual about Stargirl's behavior at sports games?

chapters.title: Chapter 8
chapters.content:
Hillari Kimble was the first to speak out against her.

Hillari Kimble was one of the most popular girls in school. She had an opinion about everything, and she wasn't shy about sharing it. She was tall and pretty and confident. People listened to her.

"She's a fake," Hillari announced at lunch one day. "She's doing it for attention."

People nodded. It made sense. It was easier to believe that Stargirl was putting on an act than to believe she was real.

"Nobody's that nice," said Hillari. "Nobody's that weird. She's playing us."

The word spread. Stargirl was a phony. She was an act. She was doing it to get noticed.

But if it was an act, it was a good one. She never broke character. She never slipped. She was Stargirl twenty-four hours a day, seven days a week.

Some kids started following her. Not to be her friend. To catch her in the act. To see her drop the mask.

They followed her to the grocery store. They followed her home. They watched her through her window.

They saw her talking to her cactus plants. They saw her dancing in her bedroom. They saw her reading books and playing her ukulele and feeding Cinnamon.

They never saw her break character. They never saw Susan. They only saw Stargirl.

And still they wondered: Was she real?

The debate raged on. Real or fake? Genuine or act? Nobody knew for sure.

Except maybe Stargirl herself.

quiz.question: Who was the first to publicly speak against Stargirl?
What did some kids do to try to catch Stargirl 'in the act'?

chapters.title: Chapter 9
chapters.content:
The football team was having a great season. They won their first game. Then their second. Then their third.

The whole school was excited. MAHS had never had a winning football team. We had always been losers. But this year was different. This year we were winners.

And Stargirl was there at every game. Cheering. Dancing. Playing her ukulele during halftime.

At first people were annoyed. She was embarrassing. She was weird. She cheered for the wrong team.

But then something strange happened. People started to like it. They started to look forward to her halftime shows. They started to cheer along with her.

She became the unofficial mascot of the football team. When she danced, the crowd danced. When she cheered, the crowd cheered.

The players loved her. They said she brought them luck. Before every game, they would find her in the stands and wave to her. She would wave back, and they would run onto the field, pumped up and ready to win.

The cheerleaders were not so happy. They felt upstaged. They felt irrelevant. They worked hard on their routines, and nobody paid attention. Everyone was watching Stargirl.

"She's stealing our thunder," complained one cheerleader.

"She's not even a real cheerleader," said another.

But it didn't matter. The crowd wanted Stargirl. And what the crowd wants, the crowd gets.

The football team kept winning. And Stargirl kept cheering. And the school kept changing.

quiz.question: How was the football team doing that season?
options: They were having a great winning season

quiz.question: How did the cheerleaders feel about Stargirl?

chapters.title: Chapter 10
chapters.content:
I started to watch her.

Not like the others, who followed her to catch her in an act. I watched her because I couldn't help it. I was fascinated.

I watched her in the hallways. I watched her in the lunchroom. I watched her at the games.

I noticed things. The way she smiled at everyone. The way she stopped to help a kid pick up dropped books. The way she seemed to float through the halls, oblivious to the stares and whispers.

I noticed the way she tilted her head when she listened to someone talk. The way she laughed—full and free, not caring who heard. The way she moved—like she was dancing even when she wasn't.

I noticed her eyes. They were large and bright and curious. They seemed to take in everything. They seemed to see things others missed.

One day I saw her in the courtyard, sitting alone under a tree. She was reading a book. Cinnamon was on her shoulder, nibbling on a sunflower seed.

I stood there watching her for a long time. She didn't notice me. Or if she did, she didn't show it.

Finally she looked up. Our eyes met. She smiled.

I felt something. I didn't know what it was. I didn't know what to call it. I just felt something.

I turned and walked away.

But I couldn't stop thinking about her. I couldn't stop watching her. I couldn't stop wondering about her.

Who was she? Where did she come from? Why was she the way she was?

And why couldn't I get her out of my head?

quiz.question: Why did Leo start watching Stargirl?
options: To catch her in an act
Because he was fascinated by her

quiz.question: What happened when Leo and Stargirl's eyes met in the courtyard?

chapters.title: Chapter 11
chapters.content:
Kevin finally asked her.

"We want you on Hot Seat," he said.

We were in the lunchroom. Stargirl was sitting alone at her usual table, eating her usual lunch: a hard-boiled egg, celery sticks, and sunflower seeds. Cinnamon was perched on her shoulder.

She looked up at Kevin. Then at me. Then back at Kevin.

"Hot Seat?" she said.

"It's our TV show," Kevin explained. "We interview students. Ask them questions. It's really popular."

Stargirl nodded slowly. "I've heard of it."

"So will you do it?" Kevin asked.

She thought about it. For a long moment she said nothing. She fed a sunflower seed to Cinnamon. She looked at me again.

"Okay," she said finally. "I'll do it."

Kevin pumped his fist. "Yes! This is going to be great!"

I didn't say anything. I just stood there, looking at her. She was looking at me too. Those bright, curious eyes.

"When?" she asked.

"Next week," said Kevin. "We'll send you the details."

She nodded. "Okay."

We walked away. Kevin was practically bouncing with excitement.

"This is going to be the best episode ever," he said. "Everyone's going to watch. Everyone."

I nodded. But I was thinking about something else. I was thinking about the way she had looked at me. Like she knew something. Like she could see right through me.

It made me nervous. And excited. And confused.

Mostly confused.

quiz.question: What did Kevin ask Stargirl to do?
options: Go on a date with Leo
Stop cheering for the other team

quiz.question: How did Stargirl respond to the invitation?
options: She agreed after thinking about it
She said she would think about it

chapters.title: Chapter 12
chapters.content:
The day of the Hot Seat taping arrived.

The studio was packed. Kids were standing in the hallways, trying to get a glimpse. Teachers had given up trying to keep order. Everyone wanted to see Stargirl on Hot Seat.

She arrived wearing a long white dress with sunflowers embroidered on it. Her hair was braided with ribbons. Cinnamon rode on her shoulder.

"No rats in the studio," said Mr. McShane, our faculty advisor.

Stargirl looked at him. "Cinnamon isn't a rat," she said. "He's family."

Mr. McShane sighed. "Fine. But if he causes any trouble—"

"He won't," said Stargirl.

She sat in the Hot Seat. The lights came on. The cameras rolled.

Kevin started with the easy questions. Where was she from? What did she like to do? Why did she carry a ukulele?

She answered them all. Simply. Honestly. Without hesitation.

Then came the harder questions.

"Is Stargirl your real name?" Kevin asked.

"It is now," she said.

"What was your name before?"

"Susan. Susan Caraway. But that didn't feel like me. So I changed it."

"You can just change your name?"

"You can change anything," she said. "If you want to."

The audience was silent. Mesmerized. I was mesmerized too.

She wasn't nervous. She wasn't defensive. She was just... herself. Completely, unapologetically herself.

It was the most amazing thing I had ever seen.

quiz.question: What was Stargirl wearing on the day of the Hot Seat taping?
options: A long white dress with sunflowers

quiz.question: What was Stargirl's name before she changed it?

chapters.title: Chapter 13
chapters.content:
The Hot Seat episode aired the next day.

It was the most-watched episode in the history of MAHS-TV. Kids crowded into classrooms to see it. Teachers stopped their lessons. Even the principal watched.

And then the questions continued. The jury—a panel of students—fired questions at her. Some were curious. Some were hostile.

"Why do you cheer for the other team?"

"Because they're people too," she said. "And sometimes they need cheering."

"Why do you dress so weird?"

"I dress how I feel," she said. "Don't you?"

"Do you think you're better than us?"

She looked surprised. "No," she said. "I think I'm me. And you're you. And that's all anyone can be."

The questions got tougher. The jury pushed harder. They wanted to break her. They wanted to see her crack.

But she didn't crack. She answered every question with the same calm, honest simplicity. She smiled. She laughed. She was completely at ease.

When it was over, the audience sat in silence. Nobody knew what to say. Nobody knew what to think.

I looked at Kevin. He was stunned.

"That was..." he started.

"I know," I said.

We didn't have words for what we had just seen. It was like watching someone walk through fire and come out the other side without a single burn.

Stargirl had conquered Hot Seat. And in doing so, she had conquered us all.

quiz.question: How popular was the Stargirl Hot Seat episode?
options: It was the most-watched episode ever
Only a few students saw it

quiz.question: How did Stargirl handle the tough questions from the jury?

chapters.title: Chapter 14
chapters.content:
After the Hot Seat episode, everything changed.

Suddenly, Stargirl was popular. Kids who had mocked her now wanted to be her friend. Kids who had ignored her now wanted to sit with her at lunch.

Girls started wearing long skirts. They started braiding their hair with ribbons. They started carrying bags like hers.

Boys started growing their hair out. They started wearing vintage clothes. They started being nicer to people.

It was like a switch had been flipped. One day Stargirl was an outcast. The next day she was a trendsetter.

People started imitating her. They started singing "Happy Birthday" to strangers. They started leaving anonymous notes of encouragement in lockers. They started doing random acts of kindness.

The Stargirl Effect, people called it. It was spreading through the school like wildfire.

Even Hillari Kimble noticed. She didn't like it.

"She's a fad," Hillari declared. "She'll be forgotten in a month."

But Hillari was wrong. Stargirl wasn't a fad. She was a force of nature.

And I was falling for her.

I didn't want to admit it. I didn't want to be like everyone else, jumping on the Stargirl bandwagon. But I couldn't help it.

There was something about her. Something I couldn't resist. Something that pulled me toward her like gravity.

I was falling. And I didn't know how to stop.

quiz.question: What happened after the Hot Seat episode?
options: Stargirl became popular and a trendsetter

quiz.question: What was 'The Stargirl Effect'?
options: People imitating her kindness and style

chapters.title: Chapter 15
chapters.content:
I found out she knew my name.

It happened in the hallway, between classes. I was walking to history when I heard someone call out: "Leo!"

I turned. It was Stargirl.

She was standing by her locker, smiling at me. Cinnamon was on her shoulder. The sun from the window behind her made her hair glow.

"Hi, Leo," she said.

I froze. She knew my name. How did she know my name?

"Hi," I managed to say.

She walked toward me. "I liked your show," she said. "Hot Seat. You and Kevin do a good job."

"Thanks," I said. My voice sounded strange. Like it was coming from far away.

"I know you've been watching me," she said.

My face went red. "I—"

She laughed. "It's okay. I've been watching you too."

She turned and walked away. I stood there, unable to move. Unable to breathe.

She had been watching me. She knew I had been watching her. And she didn't mind.

What did that mean? What was happening?

I didn't know. I couldn't think. All I could do was stand there, watching her disappear into the crowd, my heart pounding in my chest.

She knew my name. She had been watching me.

I floated through the rest of the day.

quiz.question: What surprised Leo in the hallway?
What did Stargirl reveal to Leo?
options: She hated the Hot Seat show
She had been watching him too
She wanted to join Hot Seat

chapters.title: Chapter 16
chapters.content:
She started leaving things on my desk.

A single flower. A note with a smiley face. A piece of candy. A small origami crane.

I never saw her do it. The gifts just appeared, like magic. Every day something new.

The other kids noticed. They whispered. They pointed. They laughed.

"Leo's got a girlfriend," someone said.

"Stargirl likes Leo," said another.

I didn't know what to think. I didn't know what to do. Part of me was thrilled. Part of me was terrified.

Kevin thought it was hilarious. "Dude, she's totally into you," he said.

"I know," I said.

"So what are you going to do about it?"

I didn't know. That was the problem. I didn't know what to do.

I liked her. I really liked her. But she was so... different. So unusual. So not like anyone else.

If I dated her, what would people think? What would they say? Would they laugh at me? Would they avoid me?

I was ashamed of myself for thinking these things. But I couldn't help it. I was worried about what people would think.

I wasn't brave like her. I wasn't fearless. I cared what people thought.

And that made me hate myself a little.

quiz.question: What did Stargirl start leaving on Leo's desk?
options: Small gifts like flowers and origami

quiz.question: What worried Leo about potentially dating Stargirl?
options: He was worried what people would think

chapters.title: Chapter 17
chapters.content:
She sang to me.

It was at lunch. I was sitting with Kevin, eating my sandwich, when I heard the ukulele. I looked up.

Stargirl was walking toward me, strumming her ukulele, singing.

The whole cafeteria went quiet. Everyone watched. Everyone listened.

She sang a love song. An old one, from the 1930s. Something about moonlight and roses and falling in love.

She stopped right in front of my table. She finished the song. She smiled at me.

I wanted to disappear. I wanted to sink through the floor. I could feel everyone's eyes on me. I could hear the whispers, the giggles.

But I also wanted to stand up and hug her. I wanted to tell her how amazing she was. How brave. How beautiful.

I didn't do either. I just sat there, my face burning, my heart racing.

She finished the song and walked away. The cafeteria erupted in applause and laughter.

Kevin slapped me on the back. "Dude," he said. "You're famous now."

I was more than famous. I was marked. I was Stargirl's boyfriend, whether I liked it or not.

The strange thing was, I think I liked it. I think I liked it a lot.

I just didn't know how to show it.

quiz.question: What did Stargirl do in the cafeteria?
options: She sang a love song to Leo

quiz.question: How did Leo feel about the public serenade?

chapters.title: Chapter 18
chapters.content:
We went on our first date.

She picked me up at my house. She was driving an old pickup truck that looked like it belonged in a museum. It was painted bright yellow with flowers on the doors.

"Where are we going?" I asked.

"You'll see," she said.

She drove us out of town, into the desert. The sun was setting, painting the sky orange and pink and purple. Saguaro cacti stood like sentinels along the road.

She parked at the top of a hill. Below us, the desert stretched out in every direction. The sky was enormous.

We sat on the hood of the truck and watched the sunset. She pointed out the first stars as they appeared.

"That's why I call myself Stargirl," she said. "I love the stars. They make me feel small. But in a good way. Like I'm part of something bigger."

I looked at her. In the fading light, she was beautiful. More beautiful than I had ever realized.

"Why me?" I asked. "Why did you pick me?"

She thought about it. "I saw you," she said finally. "Really saw you. And I liked what I saw."

"What did you see?"

She smiled. "Someone who's afraid to be himself. But who might be brave enough, someday."

I didn't know what to say to that. So I said nothing. We just sat there, watching the stars come out, one by one.

quiz.question: Where did Stargirl take Leo on their first date?
options: To the desert to watch the sunset

quiz.question: Why did Stargirl say she calls herself Stargirl?
options: Because she loves stars and feeling part of something bigger

chapters.title: Chapter 19
chapters.content:
We were together. Officially.

Word spread fast. Leo Borlock was dating Stargirl Caraway. The most normal guy in school was dating the weirdest girl in school.

People didn't know what to make of it. Some thought it was sweet. Some thought it was crazy. Some thought I had lost my mind.

Kevin was supportive. "She's good for you," he said. "She makes you different."

"Different how?" I asked.

"Better," he said. "Looser. More alive."

He was right. When I was with Stargirl, I felt like anything was possible. I felt like I could be anyone. Do anything.

She showed me her enchanted place—a spot in the desert where she went to meditate. She taught me to listen to the silence. To feel the earth beneath me. To notice the small things.

She showed me her happy wagon—a little red wagon she pulled around, filled with things to give away. Cookies for neighbors. Cards for strangers. Small gifts for anyone who looked like they needed cheering up.

She kept a notebook she called her "happy file," filled with newspaper clippings about good things that happened to people.

She saw the world differently than I did. She saw beauty where I saw ordinary. She saw possibility where I saw limits.

Being with her was like seeing the world through new eyes.

I was falling in love. And for the first time in my life, I didn't care what anyone thought.

quiz.question: What was Stargirl's 'enchanted place'?

chapters.title: Chapter 20
chapters.content:
The basketball team was on a winning streak.

Game after game, they won. The school was excited. Mica had never been good at sports. But this year, everything was different.

And Stargirl was at every game. Cheering. Dancing. Playing her ukulele.

She cheered for both teams, as always. When the opposing team made a good shot, she clapped. When an opposing player fell down, she ran over to make sure he was okay.

At first, this had annoyed people. But now, with the team winning, nobody seemed to mind. They were too happy to care.

"She's our good luck charm," the players said. "We can't win without her."

But there was a problem.

One of the games was against Glendale. It was a close game. Very close. In the final minutes, a Glendale player went down with an injury. The crowd cheered.

But not Stargirl. She ran onto the court and knelt beside the injured player. She held his hand. She talked to him softly.

The crowd went silent. The players stood still. Everyone watched.

The Glendale player was carried off the court. Stargirl walked back to the stands. The game resumed. Mica won.

But something had changed. People were looking at Stargirl differently now. Some with admiration. Some with confusion.

And some with anger.

quiz.question: How was the basketball team performing?

quiz.question: What did Stargirl do when a Glendale player got injured?
options: She ran to help and comfort him

chapters.title: Chapter 21
chapters.content:
The team made it to the state championship.

The whole town was excited. Mica had never made it this far. People were talking about it everywhere—in stores, in restaurants, on the streets.

The championship game was against Sun Valley. They were undefeated. They were huge. They were intimidating.

The game was close. Back and forth. Our team would score, then their team would score. The crowd was on the edge of their seats.

Stargirl cheered for both teams, as always. But this time, people minded. This was the championship. This was everything.

"Stop cheering for them!" someone yelled at her.

"Whose side are you on?" yelled another.

But Stargirl didn't stop. She kept cheering. For both teams. For everyone.

In the final seconds, Sun Valley scored. They won by one point.

Mica lost.

The crowd went silent. Then they turned to Stargirl.

"This is your fault," someone said.

"You jinxed us," said another.

"Traitor."

I stood there, watching. I wanted to defend her. I wanted to tell them they were wrong. But I didn't. I was too shocked. Too scared.

Stargirl walked out of the gym alone. I didn't follow her.

I should have followed her. But I didn't.

That was the beginning of the end.

chapters.title: Chapter 22
chapters.content:
The shunning began.

It started slowly. People stopped talking to Stargirl. They stopped sitting near her. They stopped acknowledging her existence.

At first, it was just a few people. Then more. Then everyone.

The Stargirl Effect was over. The long skirts disappeared. The ribbons came out of hair. The random acts of kindness stopped.

People who had imitated her now pretended they never had. People who had admired her now acted like they didn't know her.

She was invisible. She was nothing. She was erased.

And it spread to me too.

People stopped talking to me. They stopped inviting me to things. They stopped looking at me.

"It's because of her," Kevin said. "They're punishing you because you're with her."

"What should I do?" I asked.

"I don't know," he said. "But something. You have to do something."

I knew he was right. I couldn't take it. The silence. The isolation. The feeling of being erased.

I wasn't strong like Stargirl. I needed other people. I needed to belong.

I was starting to crack.

chapters.title: Chapter 23
chapters.content:
I went to see Archie.

Archie Brubaker was a retired paleontologist who lived in town. He was wise. He knew things. Kids went to him for advice.

I told him about Stargirl. About the shunning. About how I felt.

"She's different," I said. "Too different. She doesn't fit in."

"And that's a problem?" Archie asked.

"Yes," I said. "People don't like different. They want normal."

Archie nodded. "That's true. Most people are afraid of different. They want everyone to be the same."

"So what should I do?"

He looked at me for a long time. "What do you want?" he asked.

"I want to be with her," I said. "But I also want to be accepted. I want both."

"You can't have both," he said. "Not with her. She's too unique. Too herself. The world isn't ready for her."

"So I have to choose?"

"You have to choose," he confirmed. "Between her and them. Between being different and fitting in."

I sat there, thinking. It seemed like an impossible choice. How could I give up either one?

But deep down, I think I already knew what I would choose. I already knew which way I would go.

And it filled me with shame.

That he had to choose between her and fitting in

chapters.title: Chapter 24
chapters.content:
I asked her to change.

We were at her enchanted place in the desert. The sun was setting. The sky was beautiful. But I couldn't enjoy it.

"You have to be more normal," I said.

She looked at me. "Normal?"

"Yes. Normal. Like everyone else. Stop singing to people. Stop wearing weird clothes. Stop cheering for the other team. Just... fit in."

She was quiet for a long time. When she finally spoke, her voice was sad.

"You want me to be someone else," she said.

"No," I said. "I want you to be... less you."

As soon as I said it, I knew how terrible it sounded. But it was too late to take it back.

She nodded slowly. "Okay," she said.

"Okay?"

"I'll try," she said. "For you. I'll try to be normal."

I should have felt happy. I should have felt relieved. But I didn't. I felt like I had just done something terrible. Something unforgivable.

I had asked the most extraordinary person I knew to become ordinary. I had asked a star to stop shining.

And she had agreed. For me.

What kind of person does that? What kind of person asks someone to give up who they are?

The answer was clear: me. I was that kind of person.

And I hated myself for it.

quiz.question: What did Leo ask Stargirl to do?
options: To be more normal and fit in

quiz.question: How did Stargirl respond to Leo's request?
options: She agreed to try for him

chapters.title: Chapter 25
chapters.content:
She became Susan.

The next day at school, Stargirl was gone. In her place was Susan Caraway. Just Susan. Normal Susan.

She wore regular clothes. Jeans. A plain shirt. No long skirts. No ribbons. No flowers.

She didn't carry her ukulele. She didn't have Cinnamon on her shoulder. She didn't sing or dance or cheer for the other team.

She was quiet. She was ordinary. She was invisible.

People noticed. Of course they noticed.

"What happened to Stargirl?" they asked.

"She's gone," I said. "This is Susan now."

They looked at her. They looked at me. They shrugged.

But they didn't start talking to us. They didn't stop shunning us. Nothing changed.

Susan tried harder. She tried to join conversations. She tried to laugh at jokes. She tried to be like everyone else.

But it wasn't working. People still avoided her. People still avoided me.

I had taken away everything that made her special. And it hadn't made any difference. We were still outsiders.

I watched her trying to fit in, and I felt sick. This wasn't the girl I had fallen in love with. This was a shadow. A ghost.

I had killed Stargirl. And Susan was what was left.

What had I done?

chapters.title: Chapter 26
chapters.content:
The Ocotillo Ball was coming.

It was the biggest dance of the year. Everyone went. Everyone dressed up. Everyone had a date.

Susan wanted to go. She wanted to go as a normal girl, with a normal date, doing normal things.

"Will you take me?" she asked.

"Of course," I said.

She smiled. It was a Susan smile, not a Stargirl smile. Smaller. Dimmer. Less bright.

She bought a regular dress. Not a long flowing thing with embroidery. Just a simple dress from a department store.

She did her hair in a normal way. No ribbons. No braids. Just a simple ponytail.

She looked pretty. But she didn't look like herself.

The night of the dance, I picked her up at her house. Her parents were there. They seemed confused. They kept looking at her like they didn't recognize her.

I understood. I didn't recognize her either.

We drove to the school in silence. I kept glancing at her, looking for Stargirl. But she wasn't there. Only Susan.

"Are you okay?" I asked.

"I'm fine," she said. But her voice was flat. Empty.

We pulled into the parking lot. Music was playing inside. Lights were flashing. People were laughing.

"Ready?" I asked.

She took a deep breath. "Ready," she said.

We walked in together.

chapters.title: Chapter 27
chapters.content:
The dance was a disaster. At least for us.

We walked in, and nobody noticed. Nobody said hello. Nobody acknowledged our existence.

We stood by the punch bowl. We watched others dance. We waited for someone to talk to us.

No one did.

Susan kept smiling. Kept trying. She would wave at people. They would look away. She would try to join conversations. They would end.

I could see her breaking. Piece by piece. Her smile was getting smaller. Her eyes were getting sadder.

"Let's dance," I said.

We went to the dance floor. We danced together. Just the two of us, surrounded by people who pretended we weren't there.

And then something happened.

Someone announced the king and queen of the Ocotillo Ball.

"The queen is... Susan Caraway!"

Susan froze. I froze. Everyone froze.

Then she walked to the stage. Slowly. Uncertain. The crowd parted for her, but not out of respect. Out of avoidance.

She stood on the stage. They put a crown on her head. She looked out at the crowd.

And I could see it in her eyes. The realization. This wasn't acceptance. This was something else. Something cruel.

But she didn't run. She didn't cry. She just stood there, wearing her crown, looking at all those faces that refused to look back at her.

quiz.question: How were Leo and Susan treated at the dance?

options: Susan was named queen of the ball

chapters.title: Chapter 28
chapters.content:
Then something magical happened.

The band started playing a bunny hop. Susan was still on the stage, still wearing her crown. She looked lost. Defeated.

And then she started to dance.

Not a Susan dance. A Stargirl dance. Wild. Free. Uninhibited.

She kicked off her shoes. She let down her hair. She twirled and spun and leaped.

The crowd watched. At first they laughed. Then they stopped laughing. Then they started to move.

One person joined her. Then another. Then another.

Soon the whole dance floor was moving. Everyone was doing the bunny hop. Everyone was dancing with Stargirl.

Because that's who she was again. Not Susan. Stargirl.

She had come back. In that moment, on that dance floor, she had come back.

I stood on the sidelines, watching. I should have been out there with her. I should have been dancing beside her.

But I wasn't. I was too scared. Too worried about what people would think.

She danced and danced. The whole gym was alive with movement and music and joy.

And then she looked at me. Across the crowded dance floor, she looked at me.

And I saw it in her eyes. Sadness. Disappointment. Goodbye.

She turned and danced out the door. I never saw her again.

quiz.question: What happened when Susan started dancing at the ball?
options: She transformed back into Stargirl and everyone joined her

chapters.title: Chapter 29
chapters.content:
She was gone.

The next day, her desk was empty. The day after that, still empty. And the day after that.

I went to her house. No one answered. The curtains were drawn. The yellow pickup truck was gone.

I asked around. Nobody knew anything. Nobody had seen her. Nobody knew where she went.

It was like she had never existed. Like she had been a dream. A beautiful, impossible dream.

I went to Archie's house.

"She's gone," I told him.

He nodded. "I know."

"Where did she go?"

"I don't know," he said. "But wherever she is, she's being Stargirl. That's all she knows how to be."

"Will she come back?"

He looked at me sadly. "I don't think so, Leo. She gave you a gift. She showed you what it means to be free. To be yourself. What you do with that gift is up to you."

I didn't feel like I had received a gift. I felt like I had lost something precious. Something irreplaceable.

I walked home slowly. The streets felt empty. The world felt gray.

Stargirl was gone. And it was my fault.

options: A gift of showing what it means to be free

chapters.title: Chapter 30
chapters.content:
Life went on.

School continued. People talked. People laughed. People forgot.

Within weeks, it was like Stargirl had never existed. Her name stopped being mentioned. The long skirts disappeared for good. The random acts of kindness stopped.

Everyone went back to normal. Everyone went back to being the same.

Everyone except me.

I couldn't forget her. I couldn't stop thinking about her. I saw her everywhere—in the hallways, in the courtyard, in the desert sunset.

I kept her gifts. The flower. The origami crane. The notes. I kept them in a box in my closet, next to my uncle's porcupine necktie.

Some nights I would take them out and look at them. I would read her notes. I would remember.

And I would wonder: Where was she now? What was she doing? Was she happy?

I hoped she was happy. I hoped she had found a place where she could be herself. A place where people appreciated her. A place where she didn't have to change.

I hoped she had found what I was too afraid to give her.

Acceptance. Love. Freedom to be who she was.

I had failed her. I knew that. I would carry that knowledge with me forever.

But maybe, somewhere out there, she had found someone who wouldn't fail her. Someone braver than me.

quiz.question: How did the school react after Stargirl left?
options: Life went on and people forgot about her
Everyone changed to be like her

quiz.question: What did Leo keep from Stargirl?
options: Her gifts and notes in a box

chapters.title: Chapter 31
chapters.content:
Years passed.

I graduated from high school. I went to college. I got a job. I moved away from Mica.

But I never forgot Stargirl.

She was always there, in the back of my mind. A memory. A lesson. A reminder of what I had lost.

I dated other girls. Some were nice. Some were pretty. Some were smart. But none of them were Stargirl.

None of them made me feel the way she did. None of them showed me the world the way she did. None of them were as brave, as free, as wonderfully strange.

I often wondered what happened to her. I looked for her sometimes—on the internet, in phone books, in random crowds. But I never found her.

It was like she had vanished. Like she had returned to the stars she was named for.

Kevin and I stayed in touch. We talked about her sometimes.

"You know," he said once, "I think she changed us. All of us. Even if we don't remember it."

"What do you mean?" I asked.

"I mean, we're all a little different because of her. A little braver. A little kinder. A little more willing to be ourselves."

I thought about that. Maybe he was right. Maybe Stargirl had left something behind after all.

Maybe her gift was bigger than I realized.

quiz.question: What happened to Leo after high school?
options: He graduated, went to college, and moved away

quiz.question: What did Kevin believe about Stargirl's impact?
options: She changed everyone, making them braver and kinder

chapters.title: Chapter 32
chapters.content:
I went back to Mica once.

It was years later. I was passing through on a business trip. I decided to stop and see the old places.

I drove past the high school. It looked smaller than I remembered. I drove past the gym where she had danced. Past the courtyard where she had read her books.

I drove out to the desert, to her enchanted place. I sat there as the sun went down, watching the sky turn colors.

I thought about her. About us. About what might have been.

If I had been braver. If I had cared less about what people thought. If I had danced with her instead of watching from the sidelines.

Would things have been different? Would she still be here?

I would never know. That was my punishment. That was my regret.

I drove to Archie's house. He was old now, but still sharp. Still wise.

"Do you ever hear from her?" I asked.

"Sometimes," he said. "A postcard here and there. From different places."

"Is she happy?"

He smiled. "She's Stargirl. She's always happy."

I nodded. That was good. That was all I needed to know.

I left Mica that night. I never went back.

quiz.question: Why did Leo return to Mica?
options: He was passing through on a business trip

quiz.question: What did Archie tell Leo about Stargirl?
options: She sometimes sent postcards and was always happy

chapters.title: Chapter 33
chapters.content:
And then, on my birthday, I received a package.

There was no return address. Just my name and address, written in handwriting I didn't recognize.

I opened it carefully. Inside was a box. And inside the box was a porcupine necktie.

Not my uncle's necktie. A new one. But almost identical. The same colors. The same style. The same porcupine.

There was a note:

"Happy birthday. I never forgot."

No signature. But I knew. I knew who it was from.

She had remembered. After all these years. She had remembered my story about my uncle Pete. She had remembered me.

I sat there, holding the necktie, tears streaming down my face.

She was out there somewhere. Still thinking of others. Still giving gifts. Still being Stargirl.

I put on the necktie. It fit perfectly.

I looked at myself in the mirror. And for the first time in years, I smiled. A real smile. A Stargirl smile.

She had given me one more gift. One more reminder.

Be brave. Be yourself. Be like the stars.

Shine.

quiz.question: What did Leo receive on his birthday?

chapters.title: Epilogue: More Than Stars
chapters.content:
I still have the necktie.

Both of them, actually. My uncle Pete's and the one from Stargirl. I keep them together in a drawer, side by side.

Sometimes I take them out and look at them. Two porcupine neckties. Two gifts from people who understood something I'm still trying to learn.

Be different. Be yourself. Don't be afraid.

I'm older now. Wiser, maybe. I understand things I didn't understand back then. I see things I missed.

Stargirl wasn't weird. She wasn't crazy. She was awake. She was alive. She was everything the rest of us were too scared to be.

She saw the world as it could be, not as it was. She saw people as they could be, not as they were. She believed in the best of everyone, including me.

Especially me.

I let her down. I know that. I'll always know that. But I also know that she forgave me. The necktie proved that.

She forgave me. And maybe, someday, I'll learn to forgive myself.

In the meantime, I try to live the way she would have wanted. I try to be brave. I try to be kind. I try to notice the things that matter.

I try to be a little more like Stargirl every day.

And when I look up at the night sky, I smile. Because I know she's out there somewhere, dancing under the stars.

My Stargirl. My forever star.

More than stars.

quiz.question: What did Leo finally understand about Stargirl?
options: She was awake and alive, everything others were too scared to be

quiz.question: What is the main message of the story?
options: Be brave, be yourself, don't be afraid to be different
